support_summary: ATXN3 expression levels modulate the accumulation and phosphorylation of TDP-43, suggesting a functional, likely indirect, regulatory relationship.

functions.cellular_process: ATXN3 is involved in a protein quality control pathway that clears toxic, phosphorylated C-terminal fragments of TDP-43. These fragments are a key pathological hallmark of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD).
functions.effect_description: ATXN3 plays a protective role by promoting the clearance of toxic TDP-43 species. Loss of ATXN3 function leads to the accumulation and phosphorylation of these fragments, linking SCA3 pathology to the broader spectrum of TDP-43 proteinopathies.
biological_consequence: Clearance of Phosphorylated TDP-43 Fragments → Reduced Proteotoxicity → Neuroprotection
specific_effects: ATXN3 overexpression reduces accumulation of TDP-43 C-terminal fragments
ATXN3 knockdown increases accumulation of toxic TDP-43 fragments
Phosphorylated TDP-43 inclusions are found in SCA3 mouse models
